posts.cooked:
Is there a way to explicitly shut down the Pi rather than a hard power off? The PhotoVision webinterface doesn‚Äôt have this feature, and SSH I can‚Äôt get past the login screen. Username: Pi Password: Raspberry doesn‚Äôt work.

I‚Äôm trying to avoid SD corruption and frying the board.

Thanks

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
michjor:

Username: Pi Password: Raspberry doesn‚Äôt work.

It‚Äôs case sensitive. Camera Troubleshooting - PhotonVision Docs

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
the best way would be

https://core-electronics.com.au/guides/read-only-raspberry-pi/

another one

While there are downsides, using a read-only root filesystem will dramatically increase your Pi SD card's lifetime.

and always have spare sd card.

link_counts.title: Running a Raspberry Pi with a read-only root filesystem # Chris Dzombak

posts.cooked:
Thanks for the response. I guess following the documentation exactly as written helps!

For context the example below I am using Team 6666 but are not from there, have this setup temporarily on the secondary test bot to ensure don‚Äôt step on the main radio connection with the working robot.

When SSH directly to host IP address (SSH 10.66.66.10) asks for password and using  login fails as the user has not been defined SSH_Remote_no_user.PNG 822√ó354 68.6 KB

SSH_Remote_no_user.PNG 822√ó354 68.6 KB

SSH_Remote_no_user.PNG 822√ó354 68.6 KB

Change to (SSH **pi@**10.66.66.10) with the user name prepended to the host IP address. Now user is defined and asks for password and using  login success SSH_Remote_Pi_Success 1323√ó495 27.5 KB

SSH_Remote_Pi_Success 1323√ó495 27.5 KB

SSH_Remote_Pi_Success 1323√ó495 27.5 KB

Sudo shutdown now works as expected, shuts down gracefully and we power off the external switch SSH_Remote_Pi_Shutdown 1298√ó334 21.7 KB

SSH_Remote_Pi_Shutdown 1298√ó334 21.7 KB

SSH_Remote_Pi_Shutdown 1298√ó334 21.7 KB

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: The WPILibPi image is already set up this way (read only filesystem by default, with commands to make writable) for this exact reason.

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: I guess there‚Äôs no need to worry about that. Photon Vision doesn‚Äôt write anything to the file system unless you‚Äôre changing the configurations.

The other situation I‚Äôm trying to avoid is frying the board. The workbench is full of Pi‚Äôs that don‚Äôt even start after being turned off. We have now set up the Pi‚Äôs on their own dedicated power circuit through a buck converter and switch so when the robot is turned on and off all the time when the team is working on it, the boards aren‚Äôt getting rev‚Äôd up all the time. The policy is to gracefully shut them down the recommended way.

Would be nice if the PhotonVision page had an extra button next to the ‚ÄúRestart PhotonVison‚Äù, and ‚ÄúRestart Host‚Äù ‚Üí could have one ‚ÄúPower Down Host‚Äù so just do it from there instead.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: Generally speaking, turning it off is unlikely to fry the board. The concern here would be data bits that haven‚Äôt done writing to the SD card cause data corruption.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Actually not quite. Idk how wpilibpi solves this, but Fallback to extracting native libraries to system temp directory ¬∑ Issue #5846 ¬∑ wpilibsuite/allwpilib ¬∑ GitHub

link_counts.title: Fallback to extracting native libraries to system temp directory ¬∑ Issue #5846 ¬∑ wpilibsuite/allwpilib ¬∑ GitHub

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Do we suggest shutting down the coprocessor cleanly? I don‚Äôt remember suggesting that at least.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: The normal wpilibpi install doesn‚Äôt do any extraction of native libraries because they are already installed on the system.  The alternative would be to extract to a memory-backed filesystem as per that issue (eg /tmp is memory-backed so that would be an option).
